Chapter 3: Distinguishing Reality. Having distinguished the hindrances, we will now discuss reality.
Verse:
Reality is only tenfold, namely fundamental and characteristics,
Non-erroneous, cause and effect, and coarse and subtle reality,
Well-established, pure object of practice, inclusion, and distinctions,
Ten skillful means of reality, all for eliminating the view of self.
Discussion:

It should be known that reality is only tenfold: 1. fundamental reality, 2. characteristic reality, 3. non-erroneous reality, 4. causal and resultant reality, 5. coarse and subtle reality, 6. well-established reality, 7. pure object of practice reality, 8. inclusion reality, 9. distinction reality, 10. skillful means reality.
These are also of ten kinds, in order to eliminate the ten kinds of self-view.

The ten skillful means are: 1) skill in the aggregates, 2) skill in the elements, 3) skill in the sense bases, 4) skill in dependent origination, 5) skill in the possible and impossible, 6) skill in the faculties, 7) skill in the times, 8) skill in the truths, 9) skill in the vehicles, 10) skill in conditioned and unconditioned dharmas.
Among these, what is the fundamental reality?
It refers to the three natures: 1) the imagined nature, 2) the dependent nature, and 3) the perfected nature. The remaining realities are established based on these.
Among these three natures that have been explained, what meaning is accepted as reality?
A verse says:
It is accepted that within the three natures, one is always non-existent,
One exists but is not real, and one both exists and is real.
The treatise says:
Within these three natures,
The characteristics of the imagined are always non-existent.
Only the permanent is not existent. In this nature, it is admitted to be real, because it is not erroneous.
The dependent nature exists but is not real.
Only non-existence is real. In the dependent nature, it is admitted to be real, because it has a nature of confusion.
The perfected nature both exists and does not exist.
Only existence and non-existence are real. In this nature, it is admitted to be real, because it has the nature of emptiness.
What is the characteristic reality?
Verse:
In regard to dharmas, the individual, the grasped, and the grasper,
In existence and non-existence, there are views of superimposition and denial;
Knowing this, they do not arise, this is called the characteristic reality.
Commentary:
In regard to all dharmas and pudgalas, the views of superimposition and denial, if knowing this, they do not arise, this is the characteristic reality of the imagined nature.
The view of superimposition and the view of denial regarding the grasped and grasper, when known, do not arise. This is called the characteristic of reality of the dependent nature.
The view of superimposition and the view of denial regarding existence and non-existence, when known, do not arise. This is called the characteristic of reality of the perfected nature.
This, within the characteristic of fundamental reality, is called the characteristic of reality of appearance, because it is non-erroneous.
The reality of non-error refers to the natures of impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self, because they counteract the four errors of permanence, etc.
How should one know that these impermanence, etc. are established based on that fundamental reality?
The verse says:
The three kinds of impermanence are naturelessness, arising and ceasing, and defilement and purity;
The three kinds of suffering are the grasped, the characteristic of events, and combination;
Emptiness is also of three kinds, namely, non-existence, difference, and self-nature.
The three kinds of selflessness are the selflessness of characteristics, the selflessness of differences, and the selflessness of intrinsic identity.
These four and three kinds are based on the fundamental reality.
The treatise says:
The three kinds of impermanence are: first, impermanence due to the absence of intrinsic nature, referring to the imagined nature, because it is always nonexistent;
second, impermanence due to arising and ceasing, referring to the dependent on others nature, because it has the characteristic of arising and perishing;

third, impermanence due to the transformation of defilement and purity, referring to the perfected nature, because its state changes.ğŸ”½The three kinds of suffering are: first, the suffering of the grasped, referring to the imagined nature, because it is grasped by the clinging to persons and phenomena;
second, the suffering of the characteristics of things, referring to the dependent on others nature, because it has the characteristics of the three kinds of suffering;
third, the suffering of the combination of the two, referring to the perfected nature, because it combines the characteristics of suffering.

The three kinds of emptiness are: first, emptiness due to the absence of intrinsic nature, referring to the imagined nature, because there is no rational basis for saying it exists, and because it is said to be empty due to its nonexistence;

The second kind of emptiness is the emptiness of different natures, which refers to the dependent on others, because it is not as it is grasped by the imagination, and because it is not nonexistent in all ways.
The third kind of emptiness is the emptiness of intrinsic nature, which refers to the perfected, because it is manifested by the twofold emptiness.

The three kinds of nonself are as follows: The first is the nonself of the absence of characteristics, which refers to the imagined, because its characteristics are originally nonexistent. It is called the absence of characteristics and is said to be nonself.

The second is the nonself of different characteristics, which refers to the dependent on others, because its characteristics exist but are not as they are grasped by the imagination. It is called different characteristics and is said to be nonself.
The third is the nonself of intrinsic characteristics, which refers to the perfected, because it is manifested by nonself and is its intrinsic characteristic. It is said to be nonself.

These four kinds of nonself, impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and nonself, are each divided into three kinds in accordance with the fundamental reality. The three kinds of each of the four should be understood as above.
The true reality of cause and effect refers to the four noble truths. How are they based on the fundamental true reality?
Verse:
The three characteristics of suffering have already been explained, and the origin [of suffering] also has three kinds.
Namely, habitual tendencies, arising together, and the characteristics not yet being free from bondage.
The intrinsic nature, the non-arising of two, the two kinds of defilements and quiescence, and the three kinds of cessation.
Thorough understanding, permanent abandonment, and the realization of the three paths are the truths of the path.
Discussion:
The truth of suffering has three aspects, namely, impermanence and so forth. Each of the four has three characteristics, as already explained above.
The three aspects of the truth of the origin [of suffering] are: first, the origin of habitual tendencies, referring to the habitual tendencies of grasping at the imagined intrinsic nature;
second, the origin of arising together, referring to karma and afflictions;
third, the origin of not yet being free from bondage, referring to true suchness that is not yet free from obstructions.
The three aspects of the truth of cessation are: first, cessation by intrinsic nature, referring to the non-arising of intrinsic nature;
second, cessation of the two graspings, referring to the non-arising of the grasped and the grasper;
Third, the nature of extinction, which refers to the two of defilement and quiescence, namely cessation through deliberation and true suchness.
The four noble truths have three aspects: the path of complete knowledge, the path of permanent severance, and the path of realization.

One should know that among these, there is only complete knowledge regarding the imagined, there is complete knowledge and permanent severance regarding the other-dependent, and there is complete knowledge, realization, and attainment regarding the perfected. Therefore, the four noble truths are established based on these three.
The coarse and subtle reality refers to the conventional and ultimate truths.
How are these based on the fundamental reality?
The verse states:
One should know that the conventional truth has three distinctions,
Namely, the nominal, the functioning, and the manifest, which are respectively based on the original three.
The ultimate truth is also threefold, namely the meaning, attainment, and right practice,
Based on the original one, unchanging, and the two inversions are the perfect reality.
The treatise states:
The conventional truth is of three kinds: the first is the conventional of designation, the second is the conventional of performance, and the third is the conventional of clear expression.
These three kinds of conventional truth are established in order in dependence on the three fundamental realities.
The ultimate truth is also of three kinds: the first is the ultimate of meaning, that is, suchness, which is called ultimate because it is the object of the supreme cognition;
the second is the ultimate of attainment, that is, nirvÄá¹‡a, because it is the supreme fruit and also a benefit;
the third is the ultimate of right practice, that is, the holy path, because the meaning of the ultimate is the holy Dharma.
It should be understood that these three kinds of ultimate are established on the basis of the perfected nature among the three fundamental natures.
The perfected nature is of two kinds in general, because it is distinguished as unconditioned and conditioned.
The unconditioned is generally categorized as suchness and nirvÄá¹‡a, because it is called perfected because it is without change.
The conditioned is generally categorized as all holy paths, because it is also called perfected because it is without error with regard to its object.
The two kinds of well-established reality are, first, well-established reality as established by the world, and second, well-established reality as established by reason.
How are these two established on the basis of the fundamental reality?
A verse says:
Well-established by the world is based on the first, well-established by reason is based on the last three.
The treatise says:

If an object is commonly established by the world, habitually followed, and grasped by the understanding, and the whole world adheres to it, saying this is earth and not fire, this is form and not sound, etc., this is called well-established reality as established by the world.
This is established on the basis of the three fundamental realities, but only on the basis of the imagined nature.

If there is a meaning established by reason, it is investigated by the wise and virtuous who are able to contemplate, and is established by means of the three kinds of valid cognition. This is called well-established reality as established by reason.
This is established on the basis of the three fundamental realities.

The reality of the pure object of practice is also briefly of two kinds: the reality of the pure wisdom that is the object of practice of the afflictive obstructions, and the reality of the pure wisdom that is the object of practice of the obstructions to the knowable.
How are these two established on the basis of that fundamental reality?
Verse:
The pure object of practice is twofold, based on the one perfected.
Commentary:

The reality of the pure wisdom that is the object of practice of the two obstructions of afflictions and the knowable is established only on the basis of the perfected nature among the three fundamental realities, because the other two are not the domain of this pure wisdom.
How should one understand that the characteristics, names, conceptualization, suchness, and right wisdom are included in the three fundamental realities?
Verse:
Names are the imagined, characteristics and conceptualization are the dependent,
Suchness and right wisdom are subsumed in the perfected.
Commentary:

The five topics such as characteristics, etc., are included in the three fundamental realities according to their respective correspondences. That is to say, names are included in the imagined, characteristics and discrimination are included in the dependent, and the perfected is included in suchness and right knowledge.
The differentiated reality is briefly of seven kinds:

1) the reality of transformation, 2) the reality of true characteristics, 3) the reality of consciousness only, 4) the reality of establishment, 5) the reality of wrong practice, 6) the reality of purification, and 7) the reality of right practice.
How should one understand that these seven realities are established based on the three fundamental realities?
Verse:
Transformation, establishment, and wrong practice are based on the first two,
The true characteristics, consciousness only, purification, and right practice are based on the last one.
Commentary:

The seven such as transmigration correspond to the three fundamental realities as appropriate. That is, transmigration, establishment, and false practice are established in the fundamental dependent on others and imagined, while true characteristics, consciousness only, purification, and right practice are established in the fundamental perfected.
Skillful reality refers to the ten kinds taught in order to counteract the ten views of self.
How does one give rise to the ten views of self regarding the aggregates and so forth?
Verse:
The view of self regarding the aggregates is grasping, oneness, cause, experiencer,
Doer, freely transforming, supremacy, permanence,
Basis of defilement and purification, contemplation, and the nature of the bound and liberated.
Commentary:

Regarding the ten dharmas such as the aggregates, ten kinds of views of self are produced: 1. grasping a unitary nature, 2. grasping a causal nature, 3. grasping an experiencer nature, 4. grasping an agent nature, 5. grasping a nature of freely transforming, 6. grasping a nature of supremacy, 7. grasping a permanent nature, 8. grasping a nature that is the basis of defilement and purity, 9. grasping a nature of the practitioner, 10. grasping a nature of one who is bound and liberated.
In order to eliminate these views, one cultivates ten skillful means.
How are the ten kinds of skillful means of reality established based on the three fundamental realities?
Because the ten such as the aggregates are all included within the three fundamental natures.
How are they included within the three natures?
Verse:
The imagined, discrimination, and the nature of dharmas, their meanings are in that.
Commentary:
These ten such as the aggregates each have three meanings.
As for the aggregate of form, there are three meanings: 1. The meaning of the imagined, form refers to the imagined nature of form;
Second, the meaning of discrimination of form, which refers to the other-dependent nature of form, because in this [nature] form is discriminated.
Third, the meaning of the nature of dharmas of form, which refers to the perfected nature of form.

Just as there are these three meanings within the aggregate of form, the four aggregates such as feeling, and the nine dharmas such as the sense bases, each have three meanings, which should be understood as appropriate.

In this way, the distinctions of the aggregates, etc., by means of the three meanings, are all included within the three natures. Therefore, one should know that the ten skillful means of reality are all established based on the three fundamental realities.

Although it is said in this way that the skillful means of the aggregates, etc., are cultivated in order to counteract the ten kinds of views of self, it has not yet been explained what the separate meanings of these aggregates, etc., are.
First, how should the meaning of the aggregates be understood?
A verse says:
The meaning of the aggregates is that of not being one, of being a general summary, and of being a portion.
The treatise says:
It should be known that the meaning of the aggregates is, in brief, of three kinds:

First, the meaning of not being one, as stated in the sutras:ğŸ”½Bhiká¹£us, form is not the self. If form were the self, this form would not lend itself to suffering, and one could make it so that 'my form should be this way, my form should not be that way.'
All forms, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, coarse or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near.
Second, the meaning of general summary, as stated in the sutra:
Thus, all of these are briefly summarized into one aggregate.
Third, the meaning of division, as stated in the sutra:
It is called the aggregate of form, etc., because the characteristics of form, etc. are established separately. Therefore, the meaning of aggregate is established by this.
Moreover, it is seen in the world that the meaning of aggregate is called heap.
The meaning of the aggregates has already been explained. What is the meaning of the realms?
Verse:
The meaning of the seeds of the grasper, the grasped, and that which grasps is called the realms.
Commentary:
The meaning of the seeds of the grasper refers to the six internal realms such as the eye.
The meaning of the seeds of the grasped refers to the six external realms such as form.
The meaning of the seeds of that which grasps refers to the six consciousness realms such as the eye consciousness.
The meaning of the realms has already been explained. What is the meaning of the sense bases?
Verse:
The meaning of the door of experience and understanding of objects is called the bases.
The treatise says:
Here, the meaning of the door of experience and enjoyment is the six internal bases.
If the meaning of the door of experience and enjoyment of objects is understood, it is the six external bases.
Having explained the meaning of the bases, what is the meaning of dependent origination?
Verse:
The meaning of dependent origination is the absence of increase and decrease in cause, effect, and function.
The treatise says:
If there is no increase or decrease in cause, effect, and function, this is the meaning of dependent origination.
One should know that here, increasing the cause means taking action and so forth as having an unequal cause.

Diminishing the cause means taking it as having no cause.ğŸ”½Increasing the effect means taking it as having the arising of action and so forth conditioned by ignorance and so forth.ğŸ”½Diminishing the effect means taking ignorance and so forth as having no effect of action and so forth.
Increasing the function means taking ignorance and so forth as having a separate function in the arising of action and so forth.
The usage of diminution is to grasp that ignorance and so forth have no power at all in producing formations and so forth.
If one does not have these three kinds of grasping at increase and diminution, one should know that one is skilled in dependent origination.
The meaning of dependent origination has already been explained. What is the meaning of proper and improper conditions?
Verse:
Improper and proper conditions, purity, co-arising, and supreme mastery,
Attainment, and lack of mastery in practice - this is the meaning of proper and improper conditions.
Treatise:
The meaning of proper and improper conditions should be known in brief by seven kinds of lack of mastery.
First, lack of mastery over what is unloved - due to evil conduct, one falls into evil destinies even though one has no desire to do so.
Second, lack of mastery over what is loved - due to good conduct, one ascends to good destinies even though one has no desire to do so.
Third, lack of mastery over purity - without cutting off the five hindrances and cultivating the seven factors of awakening, one certainly cannot put an end to suffering.
Fourth, one is not free with regard to the simultaneous appearance of two Tathagatas or two Wheel-Turning Kings in one world.
Fifth, one is not free with regard to the position of a superior, as a woman cannot become a Wheel-Turning King, etc.
Sixth, one is not free with regard to the attainment of the Pratyekabuddha or unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Seventh, one is not free with regard to the performance of actions, as one who has seen the truth will never perform actions such as killing.
As for ordinary beings, they may perform such actions. This is extensively explained in the Sutra on the Many Realms. One should understand this as the proper and improper.
Thus, the meaning of the proper and improper has been explained. What is the meaning of faculties?
Verse:
The faculties have predominance in grasping, abiding, continuation, function, and the two purities.
Treatise:

The twenty-two faculties are established as having the meaning of predominance in relation to six things. The six faculties such as the eye have the meaning of predominance in relation to the grasping of objects. The life faculty has the meaning of predominance in relation to the continuation of a single life-stream. The two faculties of male and female have the meaning of predominance in relation to the continuation of a family lineage. The five faculties such as pleasure have the meaning of predominance in relation to the enjoyment of the fruits of good and evil actions. The five faculties such as faith have the meaning of predominance in relation to the purification of the world. The three faculties such as the faculty of knowing the unknown have the meaning of predominance in relation to the purification of the supramundane.
The meaning of faculties has already been explained. What is the meaning of world?
Verse:
The meaning of world should be known as cause, effect, and that which is already and not yet used.
Treatise:
It should be known that the distinctions in the three times are based on cause, effect, and that which is already and not yet used, as appropriate.
That is to say, in relation to cause and effect both already used, it is the meaning of past.ğŸ”½If in relation to cause and effect both not yet used, it is the meaning of future.
If the cause is already used but the effect is not yet used, it is the meaning of present.
The meaning of the world has already been explained. What is the meaning of truth?
Verse:
Feeling and the provisions for feeling, the activities that are their causes,
The two cessations and their antidotes, this should be known as the meaning of truth.
The treatise says:
It should be known that the truth refers to the four noble truths.
The first is the noble truth of suffering, which refers to all feelings and the provisions for feeling.
It is said in the sutras:
Because all feelings are suffering.
The provisions for feeling refer to the dharmas that accord with feeling.
The second is the noble truth of the accumulation, which refers to the activities that are the causes of that suffering.
The third is the noble truth of cessation, which refers to the ultimate cessation of the former two.
The fourth is the noble truth of the path, which refers to the path that counteracts suffering and its accumulation.
The meaning of truth has already been explained. What is the meaning of vehicle?
Verse:
By virtue, faults, and nondiscriminating cognition,
Relying on others, oneself, and liberation, this should be known as the meaning of vehicle.
The treatise says:
One should know that the vehicle refers to the very three vehicles. Herein, their meaning is shown as appropriate.
If one gives rise to this knowledge by hearing from others the merits of nirvana and the faults of samsara, and by this knowledge one attains liberation, this is the vehicle of the hearers.

If one does not hear from others the merits of nirvana and the faults of samsara, but gives rise to this knowledge by oneself, and by this knowledge one attains liberation, this is the vehicle of the solitary realizers.
If one naturally gives rise to nondiscriminating cognition, and by this cognition one attains liberation, this is called the unsurpassed vehicle.
The meaning of the conditioned and unconditioned dharmas has already been explained. What is the meaning of the conditioned and unconditioned dharmas?
Verse:
The meaning of the conditioned and unconditioned is said to be the provisional, the cause,
The characteristics;ğŸ”½If tranquil,
If the meaning observed by that.
Commentary:
Herein, one should know that the provisional refers to names, etc.;
The cause refers to the store consciousness that subsumes the seeds;
The characteristics are the body as a receptacle, the implements of enjoyment, and the mind and thought that are included in the evolving consciousnesses.
The mind is the consciousness that is always the nature of reflection.
Thought is the five consciousnesses, because they grasp present objects.
Reflection is the sixth consciousness, because it can discriminate all objects.
Thus, whether it is a conceptual designation, a cause, a characteristic, or a dharmas associated with a characteristic, it is generally called conditioned.
If it is tranquil, it refers to the cessation that is realized and the path that realizes, because they can cause tranquility.
The meaning that is observed is that which is thusness, because it is the object-support of the path of tranquility.
Thus, whether it is tranquil or the meaning that is observed, it is generally called unconditioned.
You should know that the correct knowledge that arises from the ten meanings such as the aggregates, etc., is called the skill in the aggregates, etc.
The general meaning of reality is, in brief, of two kinds: that which is able to reveal and that which is revealed as reality.
That which is able to reveal reality is the first three fundamental [realms], because they are able to reveal the others.
The revealed reality refers to the latter nine kinds, because they are revealed by the first fundamental one.
The nine revealed ones are: 1. The revealed reality of freedom from overweening pride;
2. The revealed reality of the antidote to delusion;
3. The revealed reality of the liberation of the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle;
4. The revealed reality of the liberation of the unsurpassed Vehicle, because the coarse can mature and the subtle can liberate;
5. The revealed reality of the ability to subdue the arguments of others, because one relies on analogies and principles to subdue others;
6. The revealed reality of the manifestation of the Great Vehicle;
7. The revealed reality of entering all kinds of knowables;
8. The revealed reality of the manifestation of non-erroneous true suchness;
9. The revealed reality of entering the secrets of all things grasped as I.

Chapter 4: Distinguishing the Cultivation of Antidotes. Having distinguished reality, we will now next distinguish the cultivation of various antidotes, which is the cultivation of all factors of enlightenment.
Here, we should first explain the cultivation of mindfulness.
The verse says:
Because of the causes of coarse and heavy love, the matter of self, and the absence of delusion,
In order to enter the four noble truths, one should know that one cultivates the foundations of mindfulness.
The treatise says:
Coarse and heavy are manifested through the body, therefore observing this one enters the noble truth of suffering.

Because the body has the characteristics of coarse and heavy activities, therefore coarse and heavy are the nature of the suffering of activity. For this reason, the noble ones observe that all contaminated [dharmas] are suffering.
All contaminated feelings are said to be the causes of love, therefore observing this one enters the noble truth of the origin [of suffering].
The mind is the basis and object of self-grasping, therefore observing this one enters the noble truth of cessation, because of being free from the fear of the cessation of self.
By observing dharmas, one is free from delusion regarding defiled and purified dharmas and enters the noble truth of the path.
Therefore, in order to enter the principle of the four noble truths, one first speaks of cultivating the observation of the four foundations of mindfulness.
The cultivation of the foundations of mindfulness has already been explained. The correct efforts should be explained next.
The verse says:
Having already thoroughly known the distinctions of all kinds of obstacles and antidotes,
In order to abandon and cultivate, one diligently cultivates the four right efforts.
The treatise says:
Having previously cultivated the foundations of mindfulness, one is already able to thoroughly know the distinctions of all kinds of obstacles and antidotes.
Now, in order to abandon the dharmas that are obstacles to be abandoned, and in order to cultivate the path that is able to counteract them, one diligently practices the four right efforts.
As it is said, in order to eliminate the already arisen evil and unwholesome dharmas, and so on, at length.
The cultivation of the right efforts has already been explained. The cultivation of the bases of spiritual power should be explained next.
The verse says:
Relying on the nature of abiding and being capable, in order to accomplish all matters,
Eliminating the five faults, diligently cultivating the eight kinds of abandonment.
The treatise says:

Relying on the previously cultivated effort of abandoning and accumulating, the mind then abides and becomes capable. In order to accomplish superior matters, one cultivates the four bases of spiritual power. This is because they are the causes for accomplishing all desired superior matters.
Abiding refers to the abiding of the mind, which is precisely concentration. Therefore,
Next, the four bases of supernatural power are explained after the right efforts. This capacity refers to the ability to eliminate the five faults and cultivate the eight kinds of practice.
What are called the five faults?
Verse:
Laziness, forgetting the holy teachings, and sinking, agitation,
Not practicing, practicing, these are the five faults that should be known.
Commentary:

Here, sinking and agitation are combined into one fault. If, in order to eliminate sinking and agitation, one does not apply effort, or if sinking and agitation have already been eliminated, and one still applies effort, both are faults.
In order to eliminate these five, one cultivates the eight kinds of practice.
How are their characteristics established?
Verse:
In order to eliminate laziness, one cultivates desire, diligence, faith, and tranquility,
Which are the basis, what is based on it, the cause, and the result.
In order to eliminate the other four faults, one cultivates mindfulness, wisdom, thought, and equanimity,
It is said that mindfulness is aware of sinking and agitation, subduing and extinguishing the flowing of thoughts.
The treatise says:
In order to extinguish laziness, one cultivates the four practices of cutting off:
1. desire, 2. right effort, 3. faith, 4. lightness and peace.
One should know that these correspond respectively to the basis and so forth.ğŸ”½The basis refers to desire, because effort relies on it.
The supported refers to effort, because effort arises based on desire.
The cause refers to faith, which is the proximate cause for the arising of desire that relies on the basis. If one has faith in that, then one has hope.
The result refers to peace, which is the proximate result produced by the supported effort. Because one who diligently makes effort attains supreme concentration.
In order to counteract the latter four faults, one cultivates the remaining four kinds of practices of cutting off, in the same order:
1. recollection, 2. right knowledge, 3. thought, 4. equanimity.
One should know that these correspond respectively to mindfulness and so forth.
Mindfulness refers to recollection, which is able to not forget the object and recollect the holy teachings.
Awareness of sinking and agitation means right knowledge. By the recollection of words, one is able to be aware of the two faults of sinking and agitation.
Subduing and practicing means thought. Having been able to be aware of the faults of sinking and agitation, one gives rise to practice in order to subdue and eliminate them.
Extinction and outflow means that after sinking and agitation have been eliminated, the mind then abides in equanimity and flows.
Having explained the cultivation of spiritual powers, we will now explain the cultivation of the five faculties.
How are the cultivated five faculties established?
Verse:
Having already planted the seeds conducive to liberation, one further cultivates the five superior faculties,
Namely, desire, practice, non-forgetting, non-distraction, and discernment.
Treatise:
Due to the spiritual powers, the mind has capability. After the wholesome roots conducive to liberation are fulfilled, one should further cultivate the five superior faculties:
First, the supremacy of desire; second, the supremacy of practice; third, the supremacy of not forgetting the object; fourth, the supremacy of non-distraction; fifth, the supremacy of discernment.
These five are the five faculties such as faith, in that order.
Having explained the cultivation of the five faculties, we will now explain the cultivation of the five powers.
What are the five powers?
What is their sequence?
A verse says:
The same as the hindrances to harm are called powers, established in sequence by cause and effect.
The treatise says:
The five faculties such as faith, which were explained above, have superior power and are also called powers.
This means they can subdue and eliminate the hindrances such as lack of faith, and are not overwhelmed or confused by them.
These five are established in sequence based on cause and effect, because the preceding cause attracts the subsequent effect.

That is, if one definitely believes in cause and effect, one generates effort in order to attain this effect. Having generated effort, one then abides in right mindfulness. Having abided in right mindfulness, the mind then attains concentration. Having attained concentration, one is able to know reality as it is. Having known reality as it is, there is nothing that is not accomplished. Therefore, this sequence is established based on cause and effect.
As previously explained, once the factors conducive to liberation are fully perfected, one further cultivates the five faculties.
In what stage does one cultivate the factors conducive to penetration?
Are they in the stage of the five faculties or the stage of the five powers?
The verse states:
The two pairs of factors conducive to penetration are in the stage of the five faculties and the five powers.
The treatise states:
The two kinds of factors conducive to penetration, heat and summit, are in the stage of the five faculties, while the forbearance and the supreme worldly dharmas are in the stage of the five powers.
Having explained the cultivation of the five powers, we will now explain the cultivation of the factors of enlightenment.
How are the cultivated factors of enlightenment established?
The verse states:
The factors of enlightenment are briefly five: the basis, the essential nature,
means liberation, benefit, and the three uncontaminated factors.
The treatise says:
These factors assist the enlightenment, therefore they are called factors of enlightenment.
Because of this, the factors of enlightenment are in the path of seeing, broadly there are seven kinds, briefly there are five factors.
The first is the factor that is the basis of enlightenment, namely mindfulness.

The third is the factor of liberation from enlightenment, namely vigor.

Having explained the cultivation of the factors of enlightenment, we should now explain the cultivation of the factors of the path.
How are the factors of the path established?
Verse:
Distinguishing, teaching, causing others to believe, there are three,
Opposing hindrances, also three, thus the factors of the path are eight.
Commentary:
In the stage of cultivating the path, the factors of the path are established. Therefore, these factors of the path are broadly eight, concisely four.
First, the factor of distinguishing, namely right view.
Although this is worldly, it is the subsequent attainment of the supramundane, because it can distinguish what one has realized oneself in the stage of the path of seeing.
Second, the factor of teaching others, namely right thought and one part of right speech, because it initiates speech and teaches others.
Third, the factor of causing others to believe, this has three kinds, namely right speech, right action, and right livelihood.
Fourth, the factor of opposing hindrances, this also has three kinds, namely right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.
Therefore, the factors of the path are four in brief and eight in detail.
Why are the last two each divided into three?
Verse:
Showing, seeing, precepts, and far-reaching avoidance, causing others to deeply believe and accept,
Opposing the fundamental and secondary delusions, and the obstacles to mastery, therefore.
Treatise:
The three of right speech, etc. show one's own seeing, precepts, and far-reaching avoidance, causing others to believe and accept.
That is to say, by means of right speech and the discernment of discussions, one causes others to know that one has superior wisdom.

By means of right action, one does not commit wrong actions, causing others to know that one has pure precepts. By means of right livelihood, one begs for robes, bowls, and other things in the proper amount and at the proper time in accordance with the Dharma, causing others to know that one has superior far-reaching avoidance.
The three of right effort, etc. oppose the fundamental and secondary delusions and the obstacles to mastery.
The objects of their opposition are, in brief, of three kinds:ğŸ”½The fundamental afflictions, which are to be eliminated through cultivation;
The secondary afflictions, which are torpor and restlessness;
The third is the obstacle to mastery, which is the obstacle to the excellent qualities that are attracted by the power of the mind.
Among these, right effort is specifically able to counteract the first, because in order to counteract it one diligently cultivates the path.

Right mindfulness is specifically able to counteract the second, because by fixing mindfulness and abiding in the characteristics of calming, etc., one is able to be far removed from torpor and agitation.

Right concentration is specifically able to counteract the third, because by relying on the excellent concentrations one is able to quickly attract and manifest the excellent qualities such as the supernormal powers.
How should one understand the distinctions in the cultivation of antidotes?

With non-inversion and no inversion, these are the distinctions in the cultivation of antidotes.

These three kinds of cultivation and purification are respectively present in the stages of ordinary beings, learners, and post-learners.

Chapter 5: Distinguishing the Stages of Cultivation. The antidotes have already been explained. How are the stages of cultivation?
Verse:
The stages of cultivating the antidotes are said to be eighteen,
Namely, cause, entry, practice, effect, action, non-action, superiority,
Entering, leaving, prediction, teaching,
Consecration, attainment, benefits, and accomplishing what is to be done.
The treatise says:
As explained above, the cultivation of various antidotes has eighteen types of distinctions in stages.
The first is the causal stage, referring to the person abiding in the spiritual lineage.
The second is the stage of entry, referring to those who have already given rise to the resolve.
The third is the stage of added effort, referring to those who have given rise to the resolve but have not yet attained the fruition.
The fourth is the stage of fruition, referring to those who have already attained the fruition.
The fifth is the stage of having something to do, referring to those abiding in the stage of learning.
The sixth is the stage of having nothing to do, referring to those abiding in the stage of no-more-learning.
The seventh is the stage of excellence, referring to those who have already accomplished the excellent qualities such as the supernormal powers.
The eighth is the stage of superiority, referring to those who have surpassed the Å›rÄvakas and have already entered the bodhisattva stages.
The ninth is the stage of non-superiority, referring to those who have already become Buddhas, because there is no superior stage above this.
The tenth is the stage of superior understanding and practice, referring to all bodhisattvas on the ground of superior understanding and practice.
The eleventh is the stage of realization and entry, referring to the ground of utmost joy.
The twelfth is the stage of departure, referring to the next six grounds.
The thirteenth is the stage of receiving predictions, referring to the eighth ground.
The fourteenth is the stage of eloquent explanation, referring to the ninth ground.
The fifteenth is the stage of consecration, referring to the tenth ground.
The sixteenth is the stage of realization and attainment, referring to the Dharma body of the Buddha.
The seventeenth is the stage of benefits, referring to the body of enjoyment.
The eighteenth is the stage of accomplishing what is to be done, referring to the transformation body.
Although there are many distinctions in these various stages, it should be known that they are explained in brief as being of only three kinds.
What are the three?
The verse states:
It should be known that in the Dharma realm, there are roughly three stages,
Impure, both pure and impure, and pure, as is appropriate.
The treatise states:
In the true Dharma realm, there are roughly three stages, which include the previous stages as is appropriate.
First, the impure stage, referring to the stage from the causal stage up to the preparatory stage;
Second, the stage of both pure and impure, referring to the stage of training;
Third, the stage of purity, referring to the stage beyond training.
How should one understand the establishment of pudgalas based on the distinctions of the above stages?
Verse:
Based on the distinctions of the above stages,
One should establish the various pudgalas as appropriate.
Commentary:

One should know that based on the distinctions of the above stages, one should establish the pudgalas as appropriate, referring to those who abide in the gotra, those who have already generated the mind, and so forth.

The general meaning of the stage of cultivation is as follows: The stage of capability is the same as the stage of gotra, the stage of setting out is the same as entering the stage of preparation, the impure stage, the stage of both pure and impure, the stage of purity, the stage with adornments, and the stage of pervasion, because it pervades the ten grounds. The stage without higher is the stage of no further learning.
